The audio in this video is badly edited. Either that or the presenter doesn't breath, ever. The pauses that occur between utterances when we speak are edited out in this video. That pause is useful for the listener, because, although brief, it is just long enough for the listener's mind to absorb and understand the idea just heard before the next one comes. It annoys me when editors in some YouTube videos about subjects that interest me edit out those important pauses. This video deals with an interesting subject, but the information comes to fast, so I'll have to watch it again, but I'm not sure I can be bothered.

Woh, woh, woh! SLOW DOWN! In normal crashcourse videos it is good to edit out the pauses in speech to get a quicker and more fluid video. In physics it does not work. The audience need the time to reflect on what is said, to grasp it, but the time is never given. Instead she just rushes through the script at neck breaking speed. And to top it off, throw in the occasional formula without explaining the symbols and hurriedly take it away before continuing rushing on. This could've been a great and instructive video, but sadly it isn't, because of the editing. Stop taking away all the pauses between sentences!

So how does it know what angle to refract?

Fair question, and a surprisingly complicated one. It's not about "knowledge". A photon doesn't "know" anything. The photon is merely an energized particle at the speed of light. It wants to travel in a straight line, but when it hits a surface, the realm of quantum electrodynamics comes into play. the photon is influenced by the electrons of the matter it hits. Transparent surfaces like glass influence the photon in one manner, reflective surfaces, like polished metal influence it in another manner. Long story short and honestly not quite accurate, it can be thought of as though a photon is "pushed" in the observed direction. I'd love to explain this better, but I'm almost certain that if I tried, I'd get something wrong.

in this situation it's better to think of light as a wave, not a particle. it has to do with how the wave slows down as it crosses the interface. the light bends to maintain frequency. http://img.tfd.com/mgh/cep/thumb/Physical-basis-for-Snell39s-law.jpg
if that's true it shouldn't mater how thick the glass is, any flat sheet of glass thicker then the wave length would do.

Hate to be that guy, but you really have a special ability to explain a relatively simple concept in the most confusing way possible. If your audience includes people who do not know what refraction is, then speeding through the sentence "this phenomenon of light rays changing direction at the interface between media"  is going to leave them clueless. I know the point of this channel is to teach quickly, hence "crash course", but you aren't teaching at all when you talk like that. Just some advice from a teacher. Peace.

"Sunlight, moonlight, torchlight, and flashlight. They all come from different places, but they're all the very same thing." Actually, both sunlight and moonlight have the same source. The only reason the moon "shines" at night is because it's reflecting sunlight.

It's a (near) parabolic reflective surface. Like a reflecting telescope. It acts somewhat like a convex lens the way the reflected light rays travel and converge at the focal point, except that the focal point is between you and the spoon.
UteChewb so the distance will change it rite

It's a virtual image. I mean it focuses rays like a convex lens but it is actually a concave mirror, so a virtual image. It will magnify the image at the right distance at the focal point. It will look dramatically different within, at, and beyond the focal point. I'm sure you've noticed if you have looked at a spoon or a concave mirror.
UteChewb now I wanna find some concave mirrors 🤔 thank you

Yeah, I'm a bit rusty on my optics, so don't take my word, but it is a lot of fun. What's more you can explore some amazing physics with just ordinary household things and light. Light is borderline with the quantum world so there's lots of amazing effects.
UteChewb the world is amazing as long as take the time notice 🙄
try to draw some ray diagram, it will gives you answer
maybe you should draw a ray diagram the spoon acts like a spherical mirror

The spoon acts as a Concave mirror. What happens is that the light rays from your face reflect of the spoon and are inverted. Hence the upside down image. Close enough, you'll see that its turned upright. This is because you are between the focal point and center of the mirror(spoon). On the other hand, the back side of the spoon is a convex mirror.  It will always show a virtual and erect image. It will be smaller too. Hope this helped.

Not all spoons will do this, it depends if your view point is between the focal point(s) and the spoon, or further afield. If the former then the light has not yet converged and will appear the correct way up and if the latter then the light has converged and will now appear upside down.

This is not about being right or wrong in the sense that you are stating. It's about being able to make and share observations. The religious experience is, by its very nature, entirely private. We don't have precise words to make sure we are really talking about the same things, or even close enough. And that's fine.  With the scientific method and a scientifically accurate vocabulary, we can make sure that we are indeed talking about the same things, or at least that we are doing so as much as is humanly possible, which must suffice. You could say that such a method leaves out a whole lot of human experiences - such as the religious experience. You're right, it does. That's why science doesn't deal with proving or disproving the existence of deities - it's outside of its scope, for the very simple reason that these entities are not well-defined in a scientific way.  So we know the world is not held up by a stack of tortoises because: a) this has never been observed, either directly or indirectly; and b) every other observation, confirmed and confirmed again, contradicts such a hypothesis. With both those conditions, together, we can be sure. This is what being objective means.
